ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a good understanding of the history of modern Greece, from the Revolution of 1821-29 to present day.
I learnt about the important events in Greek Modern History and how to think critically about certain periods in Greek History and why they are relevant.

I learned detailed, in depth history of Greece since approx. 1821. I gained skills of comparative political analysis and examining and weighing the various forces at play (political, social, economic) in shaping events. I gained insight into the broader development of nationalism and national myths, along with an appreciation for the various factors affecting and reasons why people ascribe to the political ideologies they do.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really enjoyed the structure of the course; it had a lot to cover but did so succinctly while not moving too fast. The only "weakness" I think was sometimes the readings were lengthy, which made discussion difficult if people hadn't read them.

I think the readings before class were a great structure. Debating about the readings in class was great given that it clarified and expanded what we read in the prior week. However, I believe that it may have been nice if Professor Aslanidis added a bit some more class lecture content to make sure we get the broad understanding of what was going on before entering the reading comprehension.

The major strengths of the course include the instructor, the readings (relevant and interesting), and the classroom presentations. The mini lectures were very helpful to learning the material. There are no significant weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely! Greece has a rich and interesting history that is often overlooked in favor of its other European counterparts, and I think Greeks, Greek diasporics and non-Greeks would all benefit from learning about it.

I would absolutely recommend this class to anyone with an interest in Modern Greece or of the Balkan area/region. There were a mixture of a few Greeks taking the class but mostly non Greeks who wanted to learn more about a country we would learn about in another class.
I would recommend the course for any student interested in general European history and/or writing research essays.
